submapp.som.Som.print_heatmap¶

Som.print_heatmap(data: numpy.ndarray = None, vmin: float = None, vmax: float = None) → None¶

Print the heatmap describing a feature of the classes

This is a visual way to detect whether referent vectors of each area of the SOM share indeed some common features (only one feature at a time though…). If within a given aera the vectors have very heterogeneous values then either the feature is not relevant with respect to the data or the SOM is not adapted to the data.

Parameters

  • data (np.ndarray[float, int], shape = (nb_class)) – Matrix whose elements describe a feature of the corresponding class. Typically data could be Som.occ_bmu_map, Som.weights_features, Som.time_info[0] or Som.time_info[1] Defaults to None, in this case, data=Som.occ_bmu_map and then the heatmap shows how much each aera of the SOM has been used during the mapping phase.

  • vmin (float, optional) – min value to anchor the colormap. Defaults to None. In this case vmin = np.min(data)

  • vmax (float, optional) – max value to anchor the colormap. Defaults to None. In this case vmax = np.max(data)

Return type

None
